timeline.subject: Marion femme Claudel Flandrey
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; accused some of them of crimes

timeline.subject: Marion femme Claudel Flandrey
timeline.details: Change de Nancy recommends she be renvoyée (released), having sufficiently purged herself of charges, subject to right of procureur to bring forward fresh evidence

notable_quotes.speaker: Marion femme Claudel Flandrey
notable_quotes.context: Denying all charges during interrogation, calling witnesses these names

notable_quotes.speaker: Marion femme Claudel Flandrey
notable_quotes.french: que sy son marit ne la veult recepvoir à sortir d'icy, qu'il le laisse et qu'elle prendra peine de se nourir, et que sondit marit vendra son bien, et nous envoyera ses enfans pour les nourir
notable_quotes.english: that if her husband does not want to receive her when she gets out of here, let him leave it and she will take the trouble to feed herself, and that her said husband will sell his property and send us his children to feed
notable_quotes.context: At end of first interrogation, expressing despair about her husband and children

notable_quotes.speaker: Beniste femme Mengeon Henryat
notable_quotes.french: que le diable ayt part des enfans
notable_quotes.english: may the devil have part of the children
notable_quotes.context: What witness said when punishing her son for taking apples from Marion's garden; son then became swollen and died

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie femme Colas Demenge le Roy
notable_quotes.french: commença à semer le bruict du mauvais gré qu'elle luy en scavoit
notable_quotes.english: began to spread the rumor of the ill will she bore her
notable_quotes.context: After Colin Humbert said he blamed Marion for sheep deaths, witness spread word of Marion's alleged ill will

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes involving economic transactions: meadow rental, debt collection (Claudel Flandrey as guardian trying to collect debt from Gregoire Vincent Henryat), sale of animals, grain sales, disputes over property boundaries and trespassing. Marion's husband owned property (meadow, garden) and served as guardian. Economic stress visible in witnesses' concerns about animal losses and their stated values (mare worth 100 francs, 6 cattle worth 50 écus). Marion's poverty suggested by witness's comment that her children came begging every day. Court order obtained in property dispute shows use of legal system.

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture on 10 June 1608; after torture failed to produce confession, on 27 June 1608 recommended she be renvoyée (released) since she had sufficiently purged herself of charges, subject to right of procureur to bring forward fresh evidence

extraction_metadata.notes: This is Marion's second trial - she was previously arrested and tortured on 4 February 1598 (approximately 10 years earlier). Notable that she withstood extensive torture without confessing in both trials. Multiple family connections to executed witches (mother's relative Didielle femme Demenge Simmonel, relative of wife of Demenge Simonel). Economic hardship evident throughout - children begging, disputes over debts and property. The Change de Nancy ultimately recommended release despite local prosecutor arguing she must have been protected by devil since she didn't seem to feel much pain during torture. Unusual features include: alleged wolf transformation, German's claim about horns, violent supernatural wind that killed Noel Ferry, and Marion's counter-accusations against witnesses. Prior trial reference is witch 239 (Claudatte femme Bastien Delat). Marion also referred to a prior trial of Agathe (first wife of Colas Jobart) but this cannot be verified. Some uncertainty about exact timing of events described as '5 years earlier,' '3 years earlier,' etc. relative to June 1608 trial date.
